html: 3.5.21  11:29 pm   i am going through a period of intense self reflection and trying to understand my place in the world. do you have any tips on speeding up this process? i would like to get to the part where i know exactly what i'm doing

      I have lots of ideas that I've recorded but I'm not really sure how to put them together.

     maybe tasting represents achieving the song's full potential, if you were doubting yourself at the time.

do it

3.5.21  12:28 pm   what is the age-old question?
3.5.21  11:55 am   i have anxiety because of my vitamin deficiency, you want to drive out to jersey to install a window for me?

3.5.21  11:42 am   okay better and more specific question now. recently I've started this approach to music where I work on an idea nonstop (can be up to 2 weeks) until I'm happy with it. this has resulted in me finally making music that I'm proud of, even though it's a stressful hell zone the entire time I'm working on it (until it finally reaches "good"). on the other hand though, doing this doesn't really help me to develop my skills on my instrument how I would like to, and I'm also spending a lot of time on one thing instead of exercising my writing muscle. and I can't make something that I like quickly for the life of me while many of my peers can and excel at this. should I continue doing what I've been doing and hope I eventually get faster/better at writing over time or switch to making a lot more stuff and spending a lot less time on it (and accepting that a lot of it will suck). or is there a completely different route I should take like working on long son gs but a lso transcribing/covering or whatever it takes to get better at my instrument and writing?
3.5.21  11:40 am   The instructions on this appliance say to have a friend help install it. Will an acquaintance do in a pinch if I don't have any friends?
3.5.21  11:28 am   What is "scarmble" supposed to be/
3.5.21  11:09 am   Do you wanna go to Mars/

3.5.21  11:05 am   should I try to get better at music by making a lot of things and spending less time on them (and accepting where it ends up by the end of the session) or by working on a single thing until I like it (regardless of how long it takes)?

     Or do I need to do both?

     The first method is attractive because I like the idea of trying to write a lot of stuff, but the second method would likely lead me to having made pieces that I can be more proud of
